description: A noun-form of Latin interloquor (“speak between, issue an interlocutory decree”), from inter- + loquor (“speak”).

entries.meaning: A person who takes part in dialogue or conversation.
examples: Explanations which continually remind one's interlocutor of one's ignorance are a great damper upon the easy flow of talk.

entries.meaning: A man in the middle of the line in a minstrel show who questions the end men and acts as leader.
examples: The "interlocutor" greeted the audience and engaged in comical repartee with the "end men," named Tambo and Bones.

description: From French interlocutoire, from Latin interlocūtōrium.

entries.meaning: (Scotland, law) A decree of a court.
examples: A decree of the English Court of Chancery is not entitled to more respect in Scotland than a decree (interlocutor) of the Scottish Court of Session in England.
